questions.text: Louis Pasteur is associated with all except_________

choices.text: Development of hot air oven and autoclave

questions.solution:
Louis Pasteur is not associated with discovery of bacillus of tuberculosis. Robert Koch discovered bacillus of tuberculosis (Koch's bacillus,1882) and the cholera vibrio (1883).

Contributions of Louis Pasteur (Father of microbiology) are:

  • Proposed principles of fermentation
  • Introduced sterilization technique and developed steam sterlizers,hot air oven and autoclave
  • Described method of pasteurisation of milk
  • Postulated germ theory of disease
  • Liquid media concept
  • Coined the term vaccine
  • Founder of Pasteur institute, Paris

questions.text: Identify the illumination system in the image below.
questions.solution:
Illumination system/ light source of microscope is marked as 2 in the image. It is a steady light source used in place of a mirror.

1 is objective lens. There are usually 3 or 4 objective lenses on a microscope. They almost always consist of 4X, 10X, 40X and 100X powers.

3 is coarse focusing knob. It moves the body tubes with its lenses.

4 is condenser. The purpose of the condenser lens is to focus the light onto the specimen.

questions.text: Mutation where the triplet code is altered so as to specify an amino acid different from that which is  normally located at a particular  position in the protein is  called _____
questions.solution:
Point mutation where the triplet code is altered so as to specify an amino acid different from that normally located at a particular position in the protein is  called Missense mutation.

Option b) Substitution of a purine for a pyramidine and vice versa in base pairing is transversion.

Option c) Deletion of a nucleotide within a gene may cause premature polypeptide chain termination by generating a  nonsense codon. This is known as nonsense mutation.

Option d) Reversal of a mutant phenotype by another mutation at a position on the DNA, distinct from that of original mutation is called as suppressor mutation.

questions.text: Which of the following codon does not terminate the message for synthesis of a polypeptide ?
questions.solution:
UUG is genetic code for leucine. It does not terminate the message for synthesis of a polypeptide i.e it is not a stop codon.

UAA, UAG, UGA do not code for any amino acid and are called stop (nonsense) codons. They act as punctuation marks terminating the message for synthesis of a polypeptide.

questions.text: In which of the following phases of the bacterial growth curve does sporulation occur?
questions.solution:
Sporulation occurs in the stationary phase of the bacterial growth curve, which is marked as C in the image.

The bacterial growth curve is obtained when a batch of bacteria is seeded in a liquid medium and incubated. It consists of 4 distinct phases:

  1. Lag phase (A) - The bacteria adapt to a new environment. They synthesize and accumulate enzymes and metabolic intermediates required for multiplication. Thus, there is no increase in cell number but cell size increases. Maximum cell size is obtained towards the end of this phase.
  2. Log or exponential phase (B) - The bacteria start dividing and their numbers increase exponentially with time. Cells are smaller and stain uniformly. The growth rate is constant. 
  3. Stationary phase (C) - There is depletion of nutrients and accumulation of toxic products. Thus, cell division reduces and a state of equilibrium is attained, where the number of new cells formed equals the number that die. Growth rate is zero. Sporulation occurs during this phase. Many bacteria produce secondary metabolic products such as exotoxins and antibiotics.
  4. Death phase or the phase of decline (D) - Growth rate is negative. The population decreases due to cell death from nutritional exhaustion, toxin accumulation and the action of autolytic enzymes. Involution forms are common.

questions.text: As per spaulding’s  classification endoscopes should be disinfected by ________
questions.solution:
As per spaulding’s classification, endoscopes should be disinfected by glutaraldehyde.

Spaulding’s classification has been used to classify the devices used on the patient. It determines the type of method selected for disinfection or sterilisation.

questions.text: Cysteine-, lactose-, electrolyte-deficient (CLED) agar medium is used in preference to MacConkey agar in relation to the culture of organisms involved in urine infection. The reason is that it  ____.

choices.text: Allows Staphylococcus and Candida to grow

questions.solution:
Cysteine-, lactose-, electrolyte-deficient (CLED) agar promotes the growth Staphylococcus, Streptococcus, and Candida.

CLED agar: It is used as an alternative to the combination of blood agar and MacConkey agar for the processing of urine specimens.

  • Advantages over MacConkey agar: It is less inhibitory than MacConkey agar and supports the growth of gram-positive bacteria (except beta-hemolytic Streptococcus) and Candida.
  • Advantages over blood agar: It can prevent the swarming of Proteus.

questions.text: Which of the following is an example of prosodemic disease?
questions.solution:
Creeping or smoldering epidemics that evolve slowly are known as prosodemic diseases. Ex: Cerebrospinal fever.

Endemic diseases: Constantly present in a particular area, e.g., malaria in Africa.

Epidemic diseases: Occurrence of cases of an illness in a community or region, which is in excess of the normal expectancy. Influenza causes annual winter epidemics in cold countries.

Pandemic diseases: Epidemic that spreads through many areas of the world involving a very large number of people within a short period, e.g., influenza, cholera.

questions.text: A patient with chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis was administered transfer factor as treatment. What type of immunity does this result in?
questions.solution:
Adoptive immunity occurs when transfer factor is given.

Transfer factor is composed of an extract of immunologically competent lymphocytes such as T lymphocytes, NK cells, macrophages, or B cells. It has the ability to passively transfer cell-mediated immunity against antigens to which the donor is sensitive.

It has been attempted in the treatment of lepromatous leprosy and chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

questions.text: The smallest unit of antigenicity is called
questions.solution:
The smallest unit of antigenicity is called the epitope or antigenic determinant. An epitope is defined as a small area present on the antigen that is capable of sensitizing immunocytes and reacting with a specific site of a T-cell receptor or an antibody.

A paratope (option B)is the specific site of an antibody that reacts with the corresponding epitope of an antigen.

Haptens are low molecular weight molecules that lack immunogenicity (cannot induce an immune response) themselves. They can become immunogenic by combining with a large molecule carrier. Haptens are classified as:

  • Complex haptens (option D): They contain two or more epitopes and can precipitate with specific antibodies.
  • Simple haptens (option C): They contain only one epitope. They bind to antibodies but are not precipitating.

questions.text: The following antigen is produced by all of the following pathogens except__________.
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a Superantigen. Enterococcus faecalis does not produce superantigens.

Superantigens are a third variety of the biological class of antigens that activate a very large number of T cells, irrespective of antigen specificity. This means they can activate T-cells directly without being processed by antigen-presenting cells (APCs).

  • The variable β region of T-cell receptor (vβ of TCR) appears to be the receptor for superantigens.
  • They directly bridge non-specifically between MHC–II of APCs and T-cells.

Examples of superantigens:

  • Bacterial
    • Staphylococcal toxin
    • Streptococcal toxin
    • Mycoplasma arthritidis mitogen 1
    • Yersinia enterocolitica
    • Yersinia pseudotuberculosis
  • Viral
    • Epstein–Barr virus (EBV)
    • Cytomegalovirus (CMV))
    • Rabies nucleocaspid
    • HIV-encoded negative regulatory factor.
  • Fungal
    • Malassezia furfur.

questions.text: Immunoglobin showing unique property of homocytotropism ______
questions.solution:
IgE exhibit unique property of affinity for the surface of tissue cells (particularly mast cells) of the same species(homocytotropism). Only human IgE can fix to the surface of human cells. It is also the only heat labile antibody, gets inactivated at 56 degree in one hour.

  • Highest for daily production, half life(23 days), serum concentration – IgG antibodies.
  • Highest for molecular weight, intravascular distribution (blood antibody), sedimentation coefficient(19) – IgM antibodies.
  • Highest carbohydrate content - IgD.

questions.text: A 20 yr old male with history of fever  and enlarged lymph nodes and sore throat was suspected to have infectious mononucleosis and was ordered a Paul bunnel test .Which of the following is the principle of the test?
questions.solution:
Paul-Bunnell test is an example of hetrophile agglutination test;done for infectious mononucleosis(caused by Epstein-Barr virus).

Here animal red blood cell antigens are used to detect cross-reacting antibodies in patient's sera.

Principle: Based on the presence of sheep cell agglutinins in the sera of infectious mononucleosis patients, which are adsorbed by ox red cells but not by guinea pig kidney extract.

questions.text: Herediatry angioneurotic edema is associated with deficiency of __________ .
questions.solution:
Deficiency of C1 esterase inhibitor is associated with hereditary angioneurotic edema.

Herediatry angioneurotic edema a condition characterised by episodic angioedema of the subcutaneous tissue or of mucosa of the respiratory or alimentary tracts.

Clinical syndromes associated with genetic deficiencies of complement components ---

Deficiency Syndrome
C1 esterase inhibitor Herediatry angioneurotic edema
Early components of classical pathway C1, C2, C4 SLE and other collagen vascular diseases
C3 and its regulatory protein Severe recurrent pyogenic infections
C5 to C8 Bacterial(Meningococcal infection), mainly with gram negative diplococci, toxoplasmosis
C9 No particular disease

questions.text: Which of the following is not a  large granular lymphocyte?
questions.solution:
Kupffer cell is not a large granular lymphocyte. It is a macrophage, phagocytic cells in liver.

When lymphocytes lack features of both T and B cells, they are called null cells (large granular lymphocytes).

  • They are double the size of small lymphocytes.
  • Consists of indented nuclei and abundant cytoplasm containing several azurophilic granules.
  • The most important member of this group is natural killer cell,others are antibody dependent cytotoxic cells and the lymphokine activated killer cells.

questions.text:
Synergohymenotropic  toxins of staphylococcus consists of:
a) Alpha lysin
b) Gamma lysin
c) Beta lysin
d) Delta lysin
e) Panton-Valentine toxin
questions.solution:
Gamma lysin and Panton-Valentine toxin (PVL) are membrane active toxins of  staph.aureus that are composed of two components (bicomponent toxins) and together called as synergohymenotropic toxins.

Synergohymenotropic toxins are a family of bicomponent toxins that act through the synergistic activity of 2 non-associated secretory proteins.

In the case of PVL, these two components are designated protein class S and F, on the basis of their slow or fast elution in cation-exchange carboxy-methyl cellulose chromatography.

These proteins are encoded by two contiguous and cotranscribed genes, lukS-PV and lukF-PV.

In S. aureus, gamma-hemolysin is another bicomponent toxin that is encoded by three genes HlgA and HlgC (belonging to class S) and HlgB (belonging to class F).

This results in 2 pairs of class S and F components - HlgA and HlgB, HlgC and HlgB.

This is an important characteristic of this class of toxins; various combinations of class S and F components result in different bicomponent toxins. These toxins create lytic pores sensitive to monovalent cations and are assembled from the two components secreted separately by the organism as water-soluble molecules.

questions.text: A patient who had been receiving ceftazidime and amikacin via central venous line for a week suddenly spiked a fever. Blood culture is positive for a vancomycin-resistant, catalase-negative organism whose Gram-stained image is given below. Identify the organism.
questions.solution:
The most likely organism involved is Enterococcus faecalis. The image shows gram-positive cocci in chains that are described as catalase-negative. This helps rule out Staphylococcus aureus and coagulase-negative staphylococcus, which are Gram-positive cocci in clusters. Streptococcus viridans is usually sensitive to penicillin and vancomycin hence it is ruled out.

The Enterococci are oval cocci arranged in short chains. They are non-hemolytic. They can cause bacteremia, especially in patients with intravascular catheters. In the USA, they are the second most common etiologic agents of central line-associated bacteremia. Recently, vancomycin-resistant enterococci (VRE) are emerging. This is due to the alteration of D-alanyl–D-alanine chains in the cell wall. Linezolid is used for the treatment of VRE.

questions.text: A patient has history of sexual intercourse with a commercial sex worker 3 days back, has developed genital discharge resembling ‘flow of seed’ . What medium should be used for culture of discharge material?
questions.solution:
It’s a case suggestive of gonococcal urethritis. The selective medium Thayer martin  is used for culture of discharge material.

Gonorrhea is a disease acquired by sexual contact. The first step in infection is infection of gonococci  to urethera or other mucosal surfaces. Pilli are involved in this adhension. The cocci penetrate the intracellular spaces and reach subepithelial tissue by third day of infection.The incubation period is 2-8 days.

In men -

Disease starts as acute urethritis with a mucopurulent discharge containing gonococci in large numbers.

The infection extends along urethera to the prostate, seminal vesicles and epididymis. Chronic urethritis may lead to stricture formation. The infection  may spread to tissuses causing abscess and multiple discharging sinuses (watercan perineum).

In women -

The intial infection involves urethra and cervix uteri. The vaginal mucosa is not usually affected in adults because of the stratified squamous epithelum and acid PH of vaginal secretions.

The infection may extend upto bartholins glands, endometrium and fallopian tube. Rarely, peritonitis may develop with perihepatic inflammation, Fitz –hugh-curtis-syndrome.

Culture-Transport-Stuart's transport medium

Acute gonorrhoea cultures can be obtained - chochlate agar OR Mueller-Hinton agar.

Mixed infections and in lesion such as proctitis - Thayer-Martin.

questions.text: Chinese restaurant syndrome after eating fried rice and vanilla sauce is due to-
questions.solution:
Chinese restaurant syndrome after eating fried rice and vanilla sauce is due to bacillus cereus.

Two types of food poisioning have been associated with B.cereus:

i) Diarrheic type - associated with a wide range of foods including cooked meat and vegetables. Characterised by diarrhea and abdominal pain, 8-16 hrs after ingestion of contaminated foods.

Vomiting is not common.

ii) Emetic type-associated almost exclusively witrh consumption of cooked rice, usually fried rice from Chinese restaurants. The illness is characterised by acute nausea and vomiting 1-5 hours after meal.

Diarrhea is not common.

Both type of illness are mild and self limiting, requiring no specific treatment.

questions.text: Which bacterium best exemplifies the information provided in the image?
questions.solution:
The image is of typical endoflagella which is a characteristic feature  of Spirochetes such as Leptospira, Treponema and Borrelia.

Endoflagella (axial filament) are the flagella like organelles in the periplasmic space encased by the outer membrane.The endoflagella begin at each end of the organism and wind around it,extending to and overlaping at the midpoint.Inside  the endoflagella is the inner membrane (cytoplasmic membrane) that provides osmotic stability and covers protoplasmic cylinder.

questions.text: Patient with history of consumption of raw cows milk. LAB investigation reveals gram positive organsims with tumbling motility:
questions.solution:
Listeria monocytogenes is short, non sporing, Gram positive bacillus, exhibiting a characteristic tumbling motility usually results from contact with infected animals, ingestion of contaminated food or milk.

Control is by preparation of food by washing of vegetables, pasteurisation of milk and thorough cooking.

questions.text: Clue cells are seen in _______
questions.solution:
Clue cells are seen in bacterial vaginosis.

Bacterial vaginosis is a polymicrobial infection characterised by a thin, malodorous vaginal discharge. Its rotten fish smell accentuated when it is mixed with a drop of KOH solution. The vaginal Ph is more than 4.5.

Clue cells are epithelial cells whose surface is covered by adherent bacilli and are seen in stained and unstained films.

Diagnosis made by Nugent’s score which is based on the morphocytes of bacteria seen on examining the gram stained smear from discharge.

questions.text: In syphilis patient , site which does not help in isolation of organism:
questions.solution:
In syphilis patient the site which do not help in isolation of organism is Gumma.Gumma is manifestation of tertiary syphilis  and tertiary lesion contain very few spirochetes and may represent manifestations of delayed hypersensitivity.

Primary chancre or hard chancre  is  a painless, relatively avascular, circumscribed, indurated, superficially ulcerated lesion, the site of entry in primary lesion. They are covered by a thick, glairy exudate rich in spirochetes.

Mucosal patch, Maculopapular skin rashes are characteristic lesions of secondary syphilis. Its due to widespread multiplication of spirochetes and their dissemination through blood. Spirochetes are abundant in these lesions and patient is more infectious in the secondary stage.

questions.text: Which of the following most likely cause necrotizing enteritis?
questions.solution:
Necrotizing enteritis (Enteritis necroticans/gas gangrene of the bowel) is caused by Clostridium perfringens C.

It is a fulminating clinical illness characterized by extensive necrosis of the intestinal mucosa and wall. It is caused by α toxin– and β toxin-producing strains, mainly by β toxin.

Immunization with type C toxoid has been shown to protect against this condition.

Note: C. perfringens type A. causes Necrotizing enterocolitis. (This is why option D is wrong)

The footnote will clear the confusion regarding option D.

questions.text: Site of action of tetanus toxin :
questions.solution:
Site of action of tetanus toxin is presynaptic terminal of spinal cord.

C.tetani produces atleast two distinct toxins - a

Hemolysin (tetanolysin) and a powerful neurotoxin (tetanospasmin).

Tetanospasmin is toxin responsible for tetanus. It resembles strychnine in its effects. It specifically blocks synaptic inhibition in the spinal cord, presumably at inhibitory terminals that use glycine and GABA as neurotransmitters. The toxin acts pre synaptically unlike strychinine. The abolition of spinal inhibition causes uncontrolled spread of impulses intiated anywhere in central nervous system. This results in muscle rigidity and spasms due to simultaneous contraction of agonists and antagonists, in the absence of reciprocal inhibition.

Minimum lethal dose for humans - 130 nanograms.

questions.text: You are performing the test shown in the image on a patient. How many days later do you ask the patient to return so that you get an accurate read on the Mitsuda reaction?
questions.solution:
Mitsuda's reaction is read in the 3rd week, i.e., on the 21st day or 20 days after the day of injection.

Lepromin test is a skin test for delayed hypersensitivity to lepra antigens. It is the only method for studying immunity in leprosy. A bacillary suspension of inactivated M. leprae is injected just under the skin.

The first reaction to occur is the early reaction of Fernandez, which consists of erythema and induration developing in 24-48 hours. It usually remains for 3-5 days; it is usually poorly defined and carries less significance. The second and more meaningful result is the late reaction of Mitsuda, starting at 1-2 weeks (7-10 days), reaching a peak in three or four weeks, and gradually subsiding over the next few weeks. On the 21st day, if there is a nodule more than 5 mm in diameter, the reaction is said to be positive. 

Note: The 21st day is 20 days after the day of injection which is counted as the 1st day.

questions.text: A 20 yr old man presented with hemorrhagic colitis . The stool sample grew escheria coli in pure culture. The following serotype of escheria coli is likely to be causative agent:
questions.solution:
E.coli serotype O157:H7 is associated with enterohemorrhagic E.coli diarrhoea and its complications like fatal hemorrhagic colitis and hemorrhagic uremic syndrome, particularly in young and elderly.

O157:H7 doesnot ferment sorbitol, unlike most e.coli strains. So the use of sorbitol Mc Conkey medium helps in screening for O157 strains.

questions.text: Farmer presents with the features of high fever, painful inguinal lymphadenopathy, vomiting and diarrhea and hypotension. Which stain will help in diagnosis?
questions.solution:
It’s a case of bubonic plague. Microscopically smears from the bubo stained with methylene blue (Wayson stain) show the bipolar stained bacilli, resembling a closed safety pin.

Points in favour of bubonic plague - Farmer: High risk  of exposure to rodents.

So stain should be used to stain the causative agent Y.pestis. The bacilli may be demonstrated in buboes by microscopy, culture or animal inoculation.

questions.text: Vibrio cholerae toxin acts by disrupting  which of these structure?
questions.solution:
Zona occludens is disrupted by Vibrio Cholerae.

Vibrio chollerae also produces additional toxins that may contribute to disease, including the zonula occludens toxin (ZOT) that alters intestinal permeability by acting on intestinal epithelial cells tight junctions and the accessory cholera endotoxin.

questions.text: A farmer presenting with fever off and on for past 4 years was diagnosed to be suffering from chronic brucellosis. All of the following serological tests would be helpful in the diagnosis at this point, except?
questions.solution:
Standard agglutination test identifies mainly IgM antibody, hence they are useful in acute but not in chronic brucellosis.

In acute brucellosis -Following 7-10 days of infection ,both IgM and IgG appear ,however the IgM antibodies gradually fall and only IgG antibodies persist in chronic brucellosis.

The complement fixation test is more useful in chronic cases as it detect the IgG antibody also.

questions.text: Which one of the following vaccines is contraindicated in children with egg allergy?
questions.solution: Vaccine contraindicated in children with egg allergy is Yellow fever vaccine (17 D strain) prepared in embryonated egg. Other vaccines are rabies vaccine (flurry strain), influenza virus (Allontoic inoculation is employed for growing the influenza virus for vaccine production).

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about bacteriophage, except?

choices.text: It is a virus that infect bacteria
It helps in transduction of bacteria

questions.solution:
Bacteriophages can transfer chromosomal as well as plasmid coded genes.eg. plasmid mediated beta lactamase resistance.

It is a virus that infects bacteria, imparts toxigenicity to bacteria. It acts as carriers of genes from one bacterium to another by transduction.

questions.text: A 70yr old women refused to take influenza vaccine, developed flu. Death occurred  1 week after pneumonia. Most common cause of Post influenza pneumonia is:
questions.solution: The most common cause of post influenza secondary pneumonia are bacterial pathogens such as staphylococcus aureus, streptococcus pneumoniae,  and haemophilus influenza.

questions.text: In a suspected patient of dengue, all of these are acceptable investigations at day 3 of presentation except:

choices.text: Viral culture and isolation in aedes albopticus c6/36 cell line
ELISA for antibody against dengue virus

questions.solution:
At day 3 of presentation ELISA for antibody against dengue virus is not done.

ELISA is the most recommended test with excellent sensitivity and specificity. It can detect IgM and IgG  separately. IgM appears first after 5 days of fever and dissappears within 90 days, followed by IgG on 14-21 days of illness.

NS1 antigen becomes detectable from day 1 of fever and remain positive upto 18 days. Its highly specific for dengue.

Dengue virus can be detected from blood one day before the onset of symptoms by inoculation into mosquito cell line or detection of specific genes of viral RNA by real time RT-PCR.

questions.text: A 25-year-old man presents with a 2-month history of loose stools and weight loss. Laboratory diagnostic tests are positive for HIV. Detection of which of the following would be most helpful in diagnosing HIV/AIDS?
questions.solution:
The acute HIV syndrome presents as acute infectious mononucleosis (glandular fever)-like syndrome.

The syndrome is characterized by the following:

General: fever, pharyngitis, lymphadenopathy, headache, arthralgia/myalgia, weight loss, vomiting/diarrhea     

Neurologic: meningitis, encephalitis, peripheral neuropathy, myelopathy

  • Lyme disease is not associated with HIV
  • Fungal infections associated with HIV-associated diarrhea are histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis, and penicilliosis, not oropharyngeal candidiasis.
  • Diarrhea in HIV patients is associated with Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) infection, but not pulmonary Mycobacterium tuberculosis (MTB) infection.

Causes of diarrhea in HIV patients:

Bacterial: Salmonella, Shigella, Campylobacter, Clostridium difficile, and MAC.

Parasitic: Cryptosporidium, Microsporidia, Isospora belli

Fungal: histoplasmosis, coccidioidomycosis, penicilliosis

Viral: Cytomegalovirus (CMV) colitis

AIDS enteropathy chronic diarrheal syndrome for which no etiologic agent is found.

questions.text: A woman presents with a positive urine pregnancy test 1 month after taking the MMR vaccine. At the time of receiving the vaccine, she had been advised to avoid conception. What advice do you give her now?

choices.text: Low risk; termination of pregnancy may be considered
High risk; serious consideration for termination

questions.solution:
In this case scenario, the doctor should advise the patient to wait and watch.

The MMR vaccine is a live-attenuated vaccine against measles, mumps and rubella. The vaccine should not be administered during pregnancy. However, some studies of women, who had mistakenly been administered the rubella vaccine (a component of MMR vaccine) during pregnancy, showed that their children did not develop congenital rubella syndrome. Therefore, if pregnancy occurs within 28 days of immunization, the patient should be counselled on the theoretical risks of the fetus developing congenital rubella syndrome, and termination of pregnancy should not be considered.

questions.text: What is the significance of the mucoid strain of Pseudomonas aeruginosa?
questions.solution:
Mucoid strains of Pseudomonas aeruginosa are able to produce a biofilm (or alginate layer).

P. aeruginosa is a gram-negative opportunist pathogen. It shows a special feature of developing a mucoid capsule in cystic fibrosis patients. This complex polysaccharide generates a biofilm that provides a hypoxic environment and thereby protects Pseudomonas against antimicrobial agents.

questions.text: Complement complex that attacks cell membrane is :
questions.solution:
Complement complex that attack cell membrane(membrane attack complex) is C56789.omplement system.

The activation and functions of complement system:

questions.text: A patient presented to a STD clinic with painful genital ulcers and soft non indurated enlarged inguinal lymph node . Identify the pathogen:
questions.solution:
Painful gential ulcers and painful, soft nonindurated enlarged inguinal lymph nodes are suggestive infection by Hemophilus ducreyi, causing soft sore or chancroid.

Related Pearl: Comparison of Genital Ulcers

  Genital herpes  Syphilitic chancre (Hard chancre) Donovanosis/ granuloma inguinale Chancroid (soft chancre) LGV
Incubation period 2-7 days

10-90 days 

Average: 21days

 1-12 weeks 1-14 days 3 days - 6 weeks
Causative agent HSV-2>HSV-1 Treponema pallidum Klebsiella granulomatis Hemophilus ducreyi

Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1,L2,L3
Clinical presentation

Cluster of vesicles on erythematous base.

Painful and pruritic lymphadenopathy

Single painless ulcer with a clean base and a firm raised border.

Painless lymphadenopathy

Painless papule or nodule erodes into beefy red granulomatous ulcer with rolled edges.

No lymphadenopathy, pseudobubos are seen

Painful ulcer (ducreyi makes you cry).

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy

Painless genital ulcer.

Painful inguinal lymphadenopathy
Diagnosis  Tzanck preparation shows multinucleated giant cells, PCR Clinical diagnosis Donovan bodies on biopsy Clinical diagnosis Nucleic acid amplification tests
Treatment Acyclovir/famcyclovir or valacyclovir Penicillin/Ceftriaxone

Azithromycin/Doxycycline

 Azithromycin/ceftriaxone  Doxycycline

questions.text: Which of the following fungal spores are formed by condensation of the hyphal elements?
questions.solution:
Arthrospores are asexual spores that are formed along the mycelium/hyphae by segmentation and condensation of hyphae.

Arthrospores are commonly formed by dermatophytes, especially those belonging to the genus Trichophyton. They are also formed by dimorphic fungi like Coccidiodes sp.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man  came to the hospital with complaints of progressive swelling of his legs. On examination, the following findings are noted. What is the best next step in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Progressive swelling of the legs with non-pitting edema and thickening of the overlying skin (image) is suggestive of lymphatic filariasis (elephantiasis). The best next step would be to test the night blood for worms since the filarial species is nocturnally periodic (between 10 pm and 4 am) in India.

Lymphatic filariasis is caused by Wuchereria bancrofti and Brugia malayi. There is obstruction of lymph vessels by adult worms, resulting in lymphangitis and leakage of lymph into tissues, resulting in hard pitting lymphedema. Fibrous tissue is laid down in tissues due to repeated lymphedema, resulting in non-pitting elephantiasis. Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice.

Other options: 

Option A: PCR is negative in chronic filariasis.

Options B & D: Lymphangiography and lymphoscintigraphy are used to assess the extent of lymphatic damage after the diagnosis of filariasis.

questions.text: A man complains  of pain abdomen ,jaundice with increased alkaline phosphatase and conjugated hyperbilirubinemia :USG shows blocade of biliary tree. What would be the cause?
questions.solution:
The findings are suggestive of infection with Clonorchis sinensis.

Patients in early stage have fever, epigastric pain, diarrhea and tender hepatomegaly. This is followed by biliary colic,jaundice and progressive liver enlargement.

Chronic infection may result in calculus formation. It is also linked with cholangiocarcinoma.

questions.text: Raynaud Braude phenomenon is seen in:
questions.solution: Raynaud braude phenomenon is other name of positive germ tube test usually seen in Candida albicans, rarely by Candida dubliniensis.

questions.text: The organism which cannot be grown on artificial media is:
questions.solution:
Rhinosporidum seeberi cannot be grown on artificial media; however, it grows in vivo in epithelial carcinoma cell culture lines.

Non cultivable fungi – Pneumocystis jirovecii and Locazia.

questions.text: The (1,3)-β-D- Glucan pan fungal detection assay is useful in the diagnosis of which one of the following infection?
questions.solution:
(1,3)-β-D- Glucan pan fungal detection assay is helpful for identification of invasive candidiasis.It is a component of the cell walls of most fungi. The main exceptions are Mucorales (rhizopus,mucor,absidia) and cryptococci ,which release no or little BG to be detected in human serum.

Beta -(1,3)-d-glucan levels greater than or equal to  80 pg/mL are positive and associated with invasive candidiasis , aspergillosis,dimorphic pathogens and other mycoses.

questions.text: A girl  goes diving in a village pond with her friend and then develops nasal discharge, meningitis and dies in 5 days. Organism responsible is:
questions.solution:
The organism is Naegleria fowleri which is the only species which infects man.

Its a pathogenic free living amoebae which causes the disease primary amoebic meningiencephalitis(PAM)

Naegleria fowleri:

  • Patients are mostly previously healthy young adults or children, infection comes from water containing free living amoeba and usually follows swimming or diving in ponds.
  • The  amoeba invade the nasal mucosa and pass through the olfactory nerve branches in the cribriform plate into the meninges  and  brain  to initiate an acute purulent meningitis and encephalitis (PAM).
  • The incubation period varies from 2 days to 2 weeks.
  • In the incubation period ,the patient experiences anosmia, disease advances rapidly ,causing fever ,headache,vomiting ,stiff neck ,ataxia,seizure and coma and ends fatally within a Week.(average 5 days).

Treatment -

Drug of choice is amphotericin -B intravenously.It can also be instilled directly into the brain.

questions.text: Disease caused by staphylocococcus aureus which is not mediated through a toxin is:
questions.solution:
Septicemic shock is not directly caused by toxins and other virulence factors play a role like protein A,fibrinolysin and coagulase,which are anti-phagocytic ,suppress host immunity and helps in  spread of infection. Septicemia is mainly due to endotoxin like activity as seen in gram negative bacilli and not due to exotoxin.

The common toxin mediated staphylococcal diseases are as follows: Food poisioning ,toxic shock syndrome,scalded skin syndrome.

Toxins of staphylococcus Aureus :

  • Cytolytic toxins:alpha hemolysin- leukocidal and neurotoxic, beta hemolysin-exhibits hot-cold phenomena,delta  hemolysin -diarrheal diseases , detergent like effect,leukocidin - induce apoptosis.
  • Enterotoxins (A,B,C1-3,D,E ,H):responsible for food poisioning .
  • Toxic shock syndrome toxin:most common enterotoxin F >enterotoxin B
  • Exfoliative /epidermolytic toxin:causes epidermolysis and scalded skin syndrome.

questions.text: Which the following filarial worms are non-pathogenic to humans?
questions.solution:
Mansonella ozzardi is generally non-pathogenic to humans. 

Option A: Onchocerca volvulus infection may manifest as skin nodules or onchocercoma which are formed as a result of fibroblastic reaction around adult worms deep in the subcutaneous tissues. Microfilariae cause lesions in the skin and eyes.

Options B and C: In lymphatic filariasis (Wuchereria and Brugia), the typical manifestations are caused by the adult worms blocking lymph nodes and vessels. Microfilaria (larval form) are responsible for allergic manifestations seen in occult filariasis.

questions.text: An orthopedician is performing the following procedure to visualize the anterior cruciate ligament in a patient. Which of the following will be used to sterilise the instrument used?
questions.solution:
The given image shows arthroscopy being performed. Arthroscopes are sterilized using plasma sterilization which utilises hydrogen peroxide. 

In plasma sterilisation, radiofrequency energy is applied to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapours are passed. This generates plasma which contains free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen. Plasma denatures all organisms and is used sterilize arthroscopes and ureteroscopes. Sterilization control is monitored by Geobacillus stearothermophilus and Bacillus atrophaeus. 

Option A: Ethylene oxide has both microbicidal and sporicidal activity. It is used for sterilisation heat-sensitive equipment like heart-lung machines, respirators, suture materials etc. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillius atrophaeus and Bacillus subtilus.

Option B: Gamma rays cause breakage of DNA. It destroys spores and vegetative cells, but is not effective against viruses. It is referred to as cold sterilisation and is used in commercial plants to sterilize plastics, syringes, swabs. Sterilization control is monitored by Bacillus pumilius. 

Option D: Ultraviolet rays are used to sterilise biosafety cabinets, entryways, operation theatres and laboratories. 

Related Pearl: Methods of sterilisation

Method of disinfection or sterilisation Material
Red Heat Inoculating wire loop, tip of forceps
Incineration Contaminated clothes, animal carcasses, plastics like polythene
Hot air oven Glasswares, scalpels, forceps, cutting instruments, test tubes
Inspissator Heat labile culture media containing egg, sugar or serum
Autoclave Culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut
Isopropyl alcohol Clinical thermometers, stethoscopes, probes
Methyl alcohol Fungal spores

Beta propiolactone/

formaldehyde

 Fumigation of operating theatres, wards and labs
2% gluteraldehyde Cystoscopes, bronchoscopes, fibre-optic endoscopes, plastic ETT, face masks
Plasma sterilisation Arthroscopes, urethroscopes
Ethylene oxide Heart lung machines, respirators, dental equipments, sutures, books, clothings
Filtration (Seitz filters) Bacterial vaccines, intravenous solutions
5% cresol, hot air oven Sharp instruments

Ionising radiation

(Cold air sterilization)

 Catgut, swabs, plastic, syringes, needles, gloves, catheters, grafts
Chlorhexidine Disinfecting surgeon’s hands prior to surgery
Iodophor Disinfecting surgical site prior to surgery
70% ethanol Disinfectant skin prior to venepuncture or immunisation
Thiomersal Preservative in vaccine
Silver sulfadiazine Cleanse burn wounds
Hypochlorite Cleanup of blood spill from a patient with hepatitis B or C
Hydrogen peroxide Cleanse wounds

questions.text: Pasteurized milk is most commonly tested by:
questions.solution:
The effectiveness of pasteurization of milk is most commonly tested by Phosphatase test.

The phosphatase test evaluates the effectiveness of pasteurization in milk by detecting the presence of alkaline phosphatase, an enzyme found in raw milk. At 60 deg C for 30 mins, this enzyme is usually destroyed. A positive result, indicated by enzyme activity, suggests inadequate pasteurization or addition of raw milk.

Other methods of bacteriological examination of milk-

  • Methylene Blue Reduction Test:  It is a microbiological assay used to evaluate the bacterial load in milk by measuring the time taken for the methylene blue dye to be reduced to colorless due to microbial activity. A shorter reduction time indicates a higher level of microbial contamination, suggesting that the milk may not be of acceptable quality for consumption. It is primarily done for raw milk for gross contamination i.e. pre-pasteurization but can also be done for pasteurized milk for post-pasteurization contamination(Option C)
  • Standard Plate count: It is done for bacteriological quality of pasteurized milk. The current standards include <30000 colonies/ml in pasteurized milk. (Option B)
  • Coliform count : Usually, coliform bacteria should be absent in pasteurized milk. Hence, their presence in the milk is suggestive of improper pasteurization or post-pasteurization contamination due to fecal contamination. (Option D)
  • Turbidity test: The turbidity test assesses milk sterilization by boiling the milk to precipitate heat-coagulable proteins, followed by the addition of ammonium sulfate and filtration. A clear filtrate indicates successful sterilization, distinguishing sterilized milk from pasteurized milk, which may show some turbidity due to residual microorganisms.
